title: How to Make Bees Wax

steps.headline: Collect as many old honeycombs as you can.
steps.description: If you keep bees yourself, you can harvest honeycombs from your own beehives. If you don’t keep bees, then ask people who do if you can have or buy some of their leftover honeycombs. Honeycombs melt down, so it may seem like you have a ton of honeycombs, but they will produce a much smaller volume of wax once you melt them.

steps.headline: Scrape honeycombs out of beehive frames.
steps.description: If you have some old honeycombs in beehive frames, then you can use a scraping tool to remove them from the frames. Press down on 1 edge of the frame to pry out the honeycombs and repeat until it all comes out. If the honeycombs come out in large chunks, use the scraper to break them up into smaller pieces. This will make it easier for them to fit into your pot.

steps.headline: Separate the clean honeycombs from the dirty ones.
steps.description: It is important to avoid melting clean honeycombs with dirty ones. If you have some honeycombs that are already quite clean, then keep those separate from the dirty ones. You can render them separately and this will reduce the amount of filtering that you need to do for the clean batch. Dirty honeycombs will look brown or even black, while clean honeycombs are light yellow in color.Safety Precaution: Be extremely careful when scraping out old frames. Make sure that there are no bees present and that you wear protective gear to collect the frames. If you are not an experienced beekeeper, then ask someone who is to collect the frames for you.

steps.headline: Place the honeycombs into a cheesecloth and tie it up.
steps.description: Spread out a piece of cheesecloth on a flat, clean surface. Place the honeycombs and honeycomb pieces in the center of the cheesecloth. Tie the opposite corners of the cheesecloth together to secure the honeycombs, or twist the corners together and tie a piece of string around the cheesecloth to keep the honeycombs inside. Repeat this if you have too many honeycombs to fit into 1 piece of cheesecloth. Keep in mind that the cheesecloth will only filter out larger particles in the bees wax, such as dead bees. However, you will need to filter the wax using a coffee filter after rendering.Tip: To avoid having to clean your wax, double or triple the layers of cheesecloth wrapped around the honeycombs. This will filter out more of the debris and decrease the chances that you will need to filter it a second time.

steps.headline: Bring a pot of water to a low boil.
steps.description: Fill a large stockpot about halfway full with tap water. Then, turn on the heat to medium-high and bring the water to a boil. Turn the heat down to low so that the water is just simmering. This will provide plenty of heat to melt the wax. Note that the wax will combine with the water as it melts, but they will separate again as the wax and water cool.

steps.headline: Use tongs to set the cheesecloth down gently in the pot of water.
steps.description: Use a pair of metal tongs to gently set the bundle of honeycombs into the pot. Don’t drop it into the water or the hot water may splash on you and burn you. Set it down in the water gently and use the tongs to push the bundle under the water fully if needed. Make sure that your tongs are made from metal or another heat-proof material. Do not use plastic tongs to set the beeswax bundle in the water.

steps.headline: Allow the wax to melt in the pot of boiling water.
steps.description: Leave the cheesecloth in the boiling water for about 10 to 20 minutes so that the honeycombs can melt. Use the tongs to press the cheesecloth down into the water if needed. You can also stir the bundle gently with a wooden spoon to help move it around. This may help to make the wax melt slightly faster.

steps.headline: Press the remaining wax out of the cheesecloth with tongs.
steps.description: Once the wax is finished melting, put on a pair of oven mitts and use the tongs to squeeze and lift the bees wax bundle out of the water by about 1 to 2 in (2.5 to 5.1 cm). Squeeze the tongs around the cheesecloth to press out any remaining bees wax still trapped inside. Then, place the used cheesecloth onto a plate or paper towel. Make sure to keep the cheesecloth over the pot while you squeeze it. Handle the cheesecloth very carefully and do not touch it with your bare hands! It will be hot.

steps.headline: Pour the melted wax into plastic containers.
steps.description: With oven mitts still on, pick up the pot and gently tip it to pour the wax into 1 or more plastic containers. Use plastic containers with lids, such as a resealable plastic container for storing food. Pour slowly and fill each container about 2/3 to 3/4 of the way full. You may also leave the wax and water in the pot that you heated them in, but it may take longer for them to cool than if you transfer them to a few smaller plastic containers.

steps.headline: Cool the wax for 2 to 3 hours and then remove the solid wax.
steps.description: The wax will take around 2 to 3 hours to cool completely, or possibly longer depending on the size of your container and the amount of wax you rendered. Once the wax is cool, you can simply remove the wax disc from the top of the water. Do not touch or stir the wax while it cools. Allow it to separate on its own. Placing the wax in your refrigerator will help it to cool more quickly, but you may have more air bubbles in your wax if you do this. There may also be pockets of water trapped in the wax if it cools too rapidly, so it is best to let it cool at room temperature.

steps.headline: Heat the solid wax in a double boiler to melt it.
steps.description: Place a heat-safe glass bowl on top of a metal pot filled with about 2 to 3 in (5.1 to 7.6 cm) of water. Then, turn the burner on low. Place the solid wax into the bowl and stir it occasionally as it melts. Turn off the heat once the wax has melted completely. A solid piece of wax will take around 10 to 20 minutes to melt, depending on its size.

steps.headline: Pour the wax through a fine colander and into a bowl.
steps.description: To filter the wax, you will need a finer filter than the cheesecloth you used to separate it from the debris inside of the honeycomb. Place a mesh colander over a bowl. Then, slowly pour the melted wax into the colander. You can also try using reusable mesh coffee filter to filter the wax. However, the wax might make coffee filter unusable, so don’t use one that goes with your coffee maker. You may have to filter a small amount of wax at a time depending on the size of your colander. Go slowly to avoid overfilling the colander.

steps.headline: Transfer the wax to smaller containers, if desired.
steps.description: After you have filtered the wax through the colander, you may pour the filtered wax into smaller containers for storage and use. Measure the amounts of wax that you want to place into each container first using a glass or plastic measuring cup. For example, if you want to separate the wax into 8  fl oz (240 mL) portions, then measure out each amount with a liquid measuring cup before you put it into a container.Tip: Cool the wax in small paper cups if you want to be able to easily remove them from the containers. Or, you can also harden the wax into specific shapes by using a silicone mold.

steps.headline: Let the wax cool for 2 to 3 hours.
steps.description: After transferring the wax into individual containers, allow it to cool at room temperature. The wax will harden and change from a translucent brown color to an opaque yellow as it dries. Avoid placing the wax into the refrigerator or freezer to speed the cooling process. It may harden more quickly, but this also increases the amount of air bubbles in the wax.

steps.headline: Use the wax to make candles, lip balm, or food wraps.
steps.description: There are many ways to use beeswax! You can make bees wax lip balm, bees wax candles, or bees wax wraps for a sustainable alternative to plastic wrap. Once your wax is finished, use it however you like.
